lines.text: Tondelayo make tiffin.

[entering for the first time, seductively]
I am Tondelayo.
The natives have been looking at me lately, in a queer sort of way.
Maybe they're wondering how you can walk without a spine.
I'm just calm now and peaceful like.
Like morphine beginning to take effect.
Or the peace of the heart, after prayer.

[applies alcohol to the native's foot]
Kind of stings, hey? You can imagine what it does to the lining of your stomach!
[takes another drink]
Did Awila no want to palaver?
No. It's too hot. I'm tired.
Do you happen to know, Mr. Langford, if they brought out my medical supplies?
I really couldn't say.
Ohh... seems a shame to waste good whiskey on sterilizing.
I'm moving out of here, Langford. Too hard on the nerves for both of us under the same roof. You keep out of my way, and I'll keep out of yours. Do your work, and don't get involved with the natives.
"Involved"?
Never let the men see that you're afraid of them. And don't mammy-palaver.
"Mammy-palaver"?
Talk to their women. Give them trinkets
Women? Why, that's ridiculous! As if I'd be interested. You're not suggesting that I might...
I'm not suggesting that you "might," I'm prophesying that you *will*.

[Noticing the Doctor crapped out in a chair, handkerchief covering his head, snoring]
That's the first intelligent sound he's made all day.

[after the going away party for Wilbur Ashley]
Say, do you fellas drink this much every night?
Unfortunately, no.
Far too much alcohol is consumed by the men of this coast. Even you, doctor, must admit that.
Well, it's more healthful to be sober, although perhaps not *quite* so pleasant.
My boy, you don't understand. That's what I'm trying to make you fight! It's a quirk that's become an obsession. It's taking away your reason! It's... affecting your mind!
Thanks. I like to be told to my face that I'm a driveling idiot.

[Witzel has just sentenced a native man to one year in prison for stealing a rifle]
You mean they're going to imprison him a whole year, for practically nothing?
The Resident has the power of life or death.
But... but, just for taking a rifle?
Yes, but didn't you understand? He shot it off... and, at Witzel!

[Slipping unexpectedly into Langford's bungalow, after months away]
How do you do, awyla?

[surprised to see her]
Where have you been all these months?
Mission at Lagos. All pray, pray, and cook, cook! Tondelayo remember much, awyla.
Why do you call me 'awyla'?
Awyla is Ibio for "my man".
Don't you ever think of anything but jewelry? You've got enough junk now to open a shop.
Just the same. You say you buy me much silk and many bangles.
Well, haven't I?
Sure... but Tondelayo want more.
Tondelayo *always* wants more.
Tondelayo must be very proud. She's "Mrs. Langford". She must have more things than anybody else!
Awyla make me sick! Always it is too hot! All time we do nothing. Awyla just sit and sit and not give hang about anything!
What am I supposed to do? Sing and dance? Be a clown?
I married to you five months, and you not beat me once.
Don't be ridiculous!
Awyla, please beat me. Then maybe you feel much better. Soon we make up. Much love. Many bangles.
Look, in a few weeks the "Queen" will be in. I've ordered you a lot of silks, and a parasol, and goodness knows what. Maybe they'll amuse you for a few days.
I've been with you for nearly three years. I think I'm just beginning to know you.
We're getting quite sentimental, aren't we?
No, we're getting quite human.
A white man can't take this African climate as a steady diet, Mr. Worthing.

We took it in the old days without any fancy refrigerators, electricity and air conditioning gadgets. Believe me, Jim, you're going to take it too. With the Japs in Malaya, we need rubber, more rubber.
Another touch of fever?
With the white man, it's always fever. With the natives, its always belly sickness.
I've told you, Witzel, a few months in a temperate climate...
Oh, drop that bedside manner. You aren't talking to Ashley, you're talking to me.
Well, at least I'm glad he's going home.

Yeah, of course, you're glad. It doesn't mean a blasted thing to you that I've got to break in a new jellyfish that they're sending out from the home office. And I know just the type he'll be. Come out here with a whole supply of stiff linen collars and ask me a million asinine questions an hour. "I say, how's the hunting?" "Are the natives friendly?" Then he'll get homesick and go back home and write a book about when you're driving in your motor do you ever stop to ponder where we get the rubber for your tires. I can't stomach any more of them.

I tell you, I cannot go on, living month-after-month, year-after-year, within the same four walls, with the same man, any longer. I'd find myself waiting for him to phrase a certain sentence in a certain way. If he did, it would drive me mad.
If were a younger man, Witzel, I would resent your innuendos.
You wouldn't resent anything with a drink hanging on the end of it.
Damp rot. Very damp with him. Its got me and another foreman and it will get you just as sure as you're sure it won't.
That's very interesting.
And I'll tell you how it will start. You'll stop shaving, regularly.
I doubt it.
I know it. And then you'll stagnate and deteriorate and, in the end, well, just remember what I told you about trinkets.
Poor devil, looks scared to death. What's he saying?
Apparently, he's stolen something. A rifle. My rifle!
Recognize him? One of your converts, isn't he?
Yes.

Yeah, well I never knew it to fail! That's what you get for pampering him. Giving him fair wages, instead of the whip. Stamping out famine and leprosy, swapping medical centers for witch doctors, bibles for voodoos. Well, maybe a dose of my medicine will be more effective than yours. Send him back to Sierra Leone, one year. Court's adjourned.
Who do you think we see last trip back in Sierra Leone?
You know, that short, little Cleopatra.
lines.character: Ted - First Mate of the Congo Queen

lines.text: Tondelayo.
Tondelayo.
Tondelayo.
Well, ha-ha-ha, who is this Tondelayo?
Oh, quite an eyeful if you should ask me.
lines.character: Ted - First Mate of the Congo Queen

lines.text: Up to her tricks again at the convent. You should see the traders, what got religion just to get around there to take a squint at that half-bred.
Its the hardest fight we have. As soon as we teach a few women to cook and sew and speak a few dozen words of our language, some white tries to turn her into his own advantage.
Why shouldn't he?
Because the end is always in the beginning. Its always the whites that become the more degraded.
She shows her nose around here, she'll get a whip across her back.
Now, isn't it ridiculous to blame her for every white man who loses his balance?

[Referring to Rev. Dr. Roberts]
Tondelayo played you for a sap. Translated your good words into bush dialect that all might hear. And then, behind your back, taught your converts to lie and cheat and steal. She's too high and mighty for the natives and too smart for the white man.
And fond of trinkets. Thanks, Witzel. Thanks for the tip.
Don't mention it.
What's the matter? What's wrong? You sent for me.
It wasn't the heat that drove Ashley crazy, it was Tondaleyo.
Well, that's interesting.
Too interesting. You're out here to work. She was picked up leaving your bungalow. What was she doing there?
Curiosity, I guess.
Yours or hers?
I don't know what this is about, but, don't be scared.
Witzel, no beat Tondelayo, eh?
Of course he won't.

Keep out of this, will you. This young fool isn't under your tricks. You'll get no silks and bangles from him because they're going to throw you out of this district, right now. And if you show your nose in here again, I'll cut my initials across your back.
Why does it annoy you that I don't live like a pig?
You didn't come out here to open a cheese shop! You haven't got what it takes. Go on back home.

Hear you say, I told you, you'd quite. I hear you say it everyday and with the same intonation. Its getting on my nerves. I'm fed up with your blasted prophecies. "You'll go native." "You'll go home."
That's where you should go, home. Every native here laughs at you behind your back.
A lot of help you've given me!
What do you think I am, a wet nurse!
I think you're a swine.
Get me a gin and lime. I said, get me a gin and lime! Don't pretend you don't understand. And I told you, for days, to fill that lamp! Gin and lime! Gin and lime!
Is it true what Witzel said, about Tondelayo being back?
How should I know.
Of course, you do know just who and what she is?
Yes, yes, yes.
She knows how to purr her way into your mind and scratch her way out. Always taking and never giving.
She's the nearest thing to a civilized woman I've seen in five impossible months.
You know you're very pretty.
I know.
Oh, please. Listen, my boy, go home. I'm begging you as I would my own son, if I had one. Go home.
And hear Witzel say I told you, you'd quit.
There goes the obsession again. Witzel! Witzel! Witzel!
Another of your prophecies gone up in smoke, Witzel. Get that, I'm marrying one of us!
What difference does that make! I'm not arguing about geography, its what she is that counts.
Soon, I'll send you to the Sisters of Lagos.
The Sisters of Lagos make me sick! I am Mrs. Langford! You cannot make me cook and pray, anymore!
Him watch Tandelayo play.
Oh, he does?
Him always near river when Tandelayo swim.
Keep away from Witzel!
Why you no ever come see me?
For the same reason I don't tread on snakes.
Tondelayo no native. Tondelayo Mrs. Langford! Tondelayo wish plenty much she wasn't.
You're stuck with that poor sap and you can't wiggle out of it. Poetic justice.
Tondelayo must always stay? No matter what she wants?

No matter wants she wants! It isn't a matter of silks and bangles anymore now. You're married and there isn't a man anywhere along this coast who will ever give you a tumble. Remember what the Padre said at the ceremony?
Him talk all the time.
I join you two in holy matrimony, 'till death do you part. That means that you're his property for as long as he lives.
